skill.name: structured-logging
skill.description: Implement JSON-based structured logging for observability. Use when setting up logging, debugging production issues, or preparing for log aggregation (ELK, Datadog). Covers log levels, context, and best practices.
skill.summary: Implement JSON-based structured logging for observability. Use when setting up logging, debugging pr...
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing logging best practices and code examples. All code is illustrative, demonstrating legitimate patterns like Pino/Winston configuration, AsyncLocalStorage context propagation, and sensitive data redaction. No executable code, no network calls, no credential access patterns. The static scanner flagged generic patterns in documentation examples that are false positives.

content.value_statement: Traditional console logs are hard to search and parse. This skill provides patterns and code examples for implementing JSON-structured logging that enables powerful filtering, aggregation, and observability across your services.
actual_capabilities: Implement Pino logger with environment-based configuration
Create Winston logger with JSON formatting
Set up request context propagation using AsyncLocalStorage
Configure sensitive data redaction in logs
Integrate logging with ELK Stack and Datadog
Define appropriate log levels for production and development
limitations: Does not install logging libraries - only provides configuration guidance
Does not handle log rotation or log file management
Does not include monitoring or alerting setup
Focused on Node.js and TypeScript implementations

use_cases.title: Production logging setup
use_cases.description: Configure structured logging for production services with Pino or Winston for better debugging and observability.

use_cases.title: Log aggregation pipeline
use_cases.description: Set up log shipping to ELK Stack or Datadog with proper trace context propagation.

use_cases.title: API request tracking
use_cases.description: Implement request ID middleware and context-aware logging to trace requests across microservices.

prompt_templates.title: Basic logger setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up Pino logger with environment-based log level, service name, and development pretty-print mode.

prompt_templates.title: Context propagation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create AsyncLocalStorage context to propagate requestId and userId across all async operations.

prompt_templates.title: Sensitive data redaction
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure Pino redact option to mask passwords, tokens, API keys, and credit card numbers.

prompt_templates.title: Log aggregation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create Winston transport that sends JSON logs to Elasticsearch for the ELK Stack.

output_examples.input: Set up structured logging for my Node.js API
output: Create logger.ts with Pino configured for JSON output
Add environment-based log level (info for production, debug for development)
Include base fields: service name, environment, requestId
Use pino-pretty transport for development readability
Configure redact option for sensitive fields

output_examples.input: How do I trace a user request through multiple services?
output: Generate unique requestId at API entry point using crypto.randomUUID()
Propagate requestId via AsyncLocalStorage across all async operations
Include requestId in every log entry for correlation
Set x-request-id header for upstream service communication

best_practices: Always use ISO 8601 timestamps for consistent log parsing across systems
Include requestId in all logs to enable distributed tracing across services
Never log sensitive data like passwords, tokens, or credit card numbers
anti_patterns: Logging unstructured strings with string interpolation instead of JSON objects
Including sensitive credentials or personal data in log output
Excessive debug logging in production causing performance issues and log bloat

faq.question: Which logging library should I choose?
faq.answer: Pino is recommended for new projects due to its minimal overhead and excellent performance.

faq.question: What log level should I use in production?
faq.answer: Use info level in production to reduce noise. Enable debug or trace only when troubleshooting.

faq.question: How do I add context to all log entries?
faq.answer: Use AsyncLocalStorage to store requestId and userId. Create a wrapper logger that includes context.

faq.question: Is my sensitive data safe in logs?
faq.answer: Configure redaction for sensitive fields using Pino redact option or custom sanitization.

faq.question: Why are my logs not appearing in ELK?
faq.answer: Ensure JSON format output, verify Filebeat can parse your format, check Elasticsearch connectivity.

faq.question: How does this compare to console.log?
faq.answer: Structured logging provides searchable JSON output unlike console.log. Enables aggregation and alerting.
